author: Stickfigure91x

description.text: This makes it much easier to switch one platen for another. It is designed to fit a Silver press from here: http://www.silkscreeningsupplies.com/screen-printing-press

Print one "plate" for each platen and one for the press. Put 3 machine screws through the plate before screwing it onto the platen. Screw another plate onto the press and bolt it in place from the other side. Insert the bolts which now protrude from the platen into the holes of the plate on the press. Secure with wing-nuts.
Now you can quickly remove a platen by unscrewing the wing-nuts and attach a different one.

Baby gate extender I designed for our classic wooden Evenflo baby gate to get past the high 1" thick baseboards where the gate wouldn't contact the wall on the one side.

Print as oriented for stronger action (layers parallel to the floor when clipped in place on the gate)

Extras: requires 7/8" rubber bumpers found at hardware stores.

remixed_from.title: Creality CR-10 Strain relief bracket for heated bed cable

title: Anet A8 Strain relief bracket for heated bed cable

description.text:
I use Greg191134's clip on my CR-10 and it works great! I keep seeing more and more complaints about fried hotbed connections in the Anet community so I snagged this to make one for myself that wasn't a chunky and ugly(IMO) chain.

Please use filament that will not warp from your bed temperature. I used annealed MakerGeek's Raptor PLA which can handle up to 125°c.

Requires:
2 small zip ties
1 grub screw (spare part that came with the A8 - yeah, probably the one that was missing from your box ;)

I left a little extra space for the bed height to accommodate for filament shrinkage during the annealing process. The grub screw squeezes into the hole to create a secure connection to the bed.
Update: I added a v2 which doesn't have the additional space to allow for shrinkage

Disclaimer:

  • I'm a n00b! This seems to be working great for me but if you use it and it explodes in a horrific fireball and wipes your whole town from the map I cannot be held responsible.

  • Please don't ask me for slicer settings or what went wrong with your print. Again, I'm a n00b. WTF do I know!?

  • Yes, you do lose some print space on the bed from this. If that's a problem for you, don't print it and don't whine to me about it 'cause ya been warned.

comments.text: Do you need to drill a hole in your bed to mount this?
comments.author: Tr1pdaddy3

comments.text: Grub screws use friction to hold objects together.  This is no different than the grub screw that holds the nozzle heater in the block.  So to answer your question directly - no.
comments.author: Tr1pdaddy3

author: Mrbear1989

description.text:
Can be installed either way over a light switch (over the existing cover) to keep the switch from being turned on, or from being turned off.  
When visiting my mother-in-law, she put blue tape over a light switch that controlled an outlet to keep the kids from turning it off. I whipped up this design and printed it out in clear PLA and she asked me to make her a bunch more!  
Enjoy!

Just print!
You can use supports if the crosspiece sags, but shouldn't be necessary.

comments.text: Just be careful if you are using something like this.  a cover like this one does indeed disable the light switch, but then it also has the risk of disabling the "OH %&*($ TURN IT OFF!" of a light switch when someone is getting shocked, or a bulb is being replaced, or a flood, etc.

Notes:

The tubes on the inside of the cap are the support - designed in, so that you should not need support in slicing. The threads also have built-in support. I printed with PLA, no supports. You might need to rotate the STL in your slicer to get it flat on the bed surface (-90 on x axis using Slic3r in my case).

Cut off the support tubes under the cap after printing, using flush cutters or exacto blade. The first pic shows the original cap compared to this print. The support tubes are cut.

Optionally you can cut off the 3 support tabs under the cap threads, but likely you can just leave those there, it should not affect operation.

Used for teleportation to buildings and shrines.

Cost: 50 gold
"What a hero truly needs."

Dimensions: ~ 70 x 82 x 15 mm

Notes:
-Double clicking the item while being at least 1500 range away from the team's fountain, automatically targets the fountain's location.
-If multiple heroes teleport to the same location within the check duration, the channeling time increases for each successive hero.
-The first channel takes 3 seconds, the second 5 seconds, and all following channels take 0.5 seconds longer than the previous one.
-Only teleports within 1150 radius of towers are counted. Teleports outside of tower range do not increase the channel time.
-Only teleports from other Town Portal Scrolls are counted. Other sources of teleport (e.g. Boots of Travel) are ignored.
-The teleports do not have to succeed. A canceled teleport still counts and increases following teleport's channeling time.
-When targeting far away from buildings, it teleports to the closest building, 575 range away from it.
-Has a max distance of 250 when targeting the shrines outside of the base.
-During the channeling, the teleport destination is marked with a visual effect in the same color as the player and a sound is played.
-Both are visible and audible to everyone. The visual effect is also visible on teleporting invisible enemies.
-Also marks the point on the minimap for allies. The mark is in the player's color and lasts as long as the channeling does.
-Provides 200 range flying vision at the destination point for the whole channel duration, even if cancelled. The vision lingers for 1 second.
-The teleport is not cancelled when the target building is destroyed during the channeling.
Shares cooldown with Boots of Travel 1 icon.png Boots of Travel.

Information and picture taken from http://dota2.gamepedia.com/Town_Portal_Scroll

New heavy duty flashlight design, feel free to customize it for your needs! I used a 3750mAh 1S3P LiPoly battery (it works for ~10h continuously with 1W LED). Made it in Autodesk Inventor, files included!
Use some support as it has some overhanging regions.

Other parts needed:
1W LED
LiPo battery (or anything else)
connectors for the battery
some cable
1.5Ohm resistor (depends on the other parts used, works perfectly with ~200mm Kanthal wire)
3x M3 screws

(My Inventor saves everything shrinked by 10, so set "scale" to 1000% for accurate sizes!)
Happy printing!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a lithophane cube, made for 130mm square lithophanes, that sits on and rotates on a base. The custom base and platter that attaches at the top of it are made to accept a candelabra lighting kit (http://www.homedepot.com/p/Westinghouse-6-ft-Cord-Set-with-Snap-In-Pigtail-Candelabra-Base-Socket-and-Cord-Switch-7010800/204836010). I put a 40W LED bulb that I picked up for about $3 from Walmart in it. The modified base of the original "thing" then sits down on the assembled stand.

Because the lithophane cube rests on a round plate that lines up with a round hole in the cube base, you can revolve/rotate the cube around and see all sides of it while the base/lighting stays stationary. It also makes the cube easy to lift off and disassemble in case you wish to swap out the lithophanes. The base also adds some height to the original cube structure so that the final result is about 8.5" from corner to corner and 8.5" high.

For the complete frame and base, print the three STL files here and the top and four corners from the "thing" from which this derived (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1370792).

If you are interested in lithophanes, these pieces plus a lot of others are posted in the files section of the Lithophanes group on Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/groups/Lithophanes).

The pictures show my initials and the year in the finished base of the cube. Don't worry, That is not in the STL file, but just in the finished product that I made for a family member. :)

UPDATE: After reports that the original cube files that this was intended to work with had changed, I uploaded a ZIP file that contains all the parts for the full cube - just add your own lithophanes.

SECOND UPDATE: I uploaded the original files in STEP and Fusion 360 formats for those who want to do things like change the light connector or eliminate the cut-out for the cord. Please mark that you are doing a derivative though so I can see how this thing evolves.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Because the plate that sits on the base is a separate part, both can be printed with no supports. I print the base with 15% infill. I increased the infill to 25% for the round platter and the base of the cube. I made the top of the cube with the same 25% infill.

Because this is going to be an heirloom piece, I printed all the pieces at a layer height of .15mm and a slow 45mm speed. The result is beautiful. But it did take 75 hours to print, so there is a price for that.

description.text:
A two part mounting bracket that provides a pair of M3 screw mount points on the Z Axis of an Original Prusa i3 Mk2s.

Goes on easy, stays in place solidly, and you don't need to design a clip mount into every part you make.

I wanted a corner radius template for making nice rounded edges on woodworking projects. I saw a few, but didn't like them for one reason or another. I tend to make a lot of small projects and want something for the router table. I also wanted features to keep my fingers far away from the bit. I included a 1, 1.5, 2, and 2.5" radius. I am open to requests for other sizes.

I have only used the 1" so far, but with excellent results. Printed in cheap PLA, it held up well to the bearing. If you do a lot of corners at once, the bit might get hot and melt the plastic template. If you are having issues, try a higher temp plastic. No support should be needed. More pictures and info on my website
http://kiltedcraftworks.com/2017/07/16/corner-radius-routing-jig

title: Sea Ray Sundancer 500 Yacht UPDATED
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model I created based off of a 1997 Sea Ray Sundancer 500. It was designed to be given as a gift and displayed as a model, the railings and other features will not hold up to being played with like a toy. I created the model using Catia and printed it on my Prusa I3 MK2s.

I also attached a file for a stand to hold the boat for display.

UPDATE: 7/17/17
I edited both the boat STL file and the factory file.

I had to combine part bodies in my Catia file and then export as an STL to get a better output for printing.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

1.5

Infill:

30

Notes:

I recommend printing the model in a scale of 1000%-2000% because it was created in inches.

To slice the model I used Simplify 3D.

UPDATE: 7/17/17

I have updated the factory file and support locations.

My recommended print settings have changed to
1.5mm layer height
30% infill
1.5mm support resolution

For supports you want to use the custom support tool feature. I first generated automatic support coming from the build platform only. I then went and manually add the supports under the windshield and cross beam. You can see the support locations as showcased in one of the pictures.

description.text: I got tired of using one bolt to hold my turn signal bracket to the upper triple while the other bolt held a bushing and a stack of washers. This part, when combined with 10mm tall bushings I cut from 1/2" steel tube (Lowe's), provides a cleaner solution to the problem of maintaining turning radius on an XR650L with a large aftermarket gas tank. The parts labelled as "27 degree rake" make the horizontal leg of the bracket parallel to the ground on an XR650L with stock forks. ***Unlike the other moto parts I've uploaded, this one has not been tested for any period of time yet. The testing starts today. My experience with PCTPE makes me confident that it will hold up.

description.text: I made this so I could turn my ceiling fan light off from my bed. I don't know if this will work on everyone's ceiling fans, but if it has a pull cord, and a small cylinder housing it probably will. This just adds another cord to your ceiling fan, you can still use the original pull cord.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There are 2 axles, and 2 wheels. They are both the same for each frame, so make sure to print 2 sets. One frame attaches to the ceiling fan my snapping over the housing where the pull cord comes out (make sure you tie a string to it as close as you can to where the pull cord enters the fan housing. This string will be the new extended pull cord). The other frame attaches to the wall with a single wood screw (there shouldn't be much force to turn on the light this way, so I used a 1.5" wood screw into drywall). The wheels are then put in place, and the axles pass through the frame, wheel, and into the other hole on the frame. You will see a 15mm indented circle on one side of both of the frames. The axle starts on that side, and then is snapped into place on the with the 15mm circle on the axle.

YOU NEED A COUNTER WEIGHT ON THE END OF THE STRING TO KEEP THE STRING FROM GETTING SLACK. ALSO MOUNT THE FRAME THAT'S ATTACHED TO THE WALL A LITTLE LOWER, SO IT DOESN'T TANGLE WITH THE CEILING FAN BLADES.

This is a motor or shaft mount for a 25mm diameter cylinder. Both parts are necessary. Depending on your setup you may need to scale the parts by 25.4 for a metric conversion. There are general drawings with overall dimensions in inches in the photos above.

The hole is slightly undersized, and fastening the U shaped piece to a board makes the mount act like a shaft collar and grip the motor or shaft. This wouldn't hold against high torque, but can hold or align a motor under low load.

The mounting holes are 1/4" clearance holes spaced 2" apart.

CAD Via Onshape

http://bit.ly/25mmMotorMountCAD

Print the foot, screw the microphone stand adapter that hopefully came with your microphone on it, and insert your microphone. If the adapter is height adjustable, so is your microphone.

The foot doesn't have printed threads; The threads on the adapter are supposed cut into the bolt on the foot (which has a diameter of 15.5 mm), forming its own threads.

This thing is designed to be simple, easy to print, and give good results with a variety of print settings.

  • Zero overhangs.
  • Rounded perimeter helps prevent lifting corners.
  • The print only has one island (or no islands, if you will), except for a few layers in the middle where there are two. This means fewer retractions.
  • Can be printed solid without using a ton of material. (Can also be printed with thick walls and/or high infill, depending on what properties you want.)

• PLA: 18 g
  • Microphone stand adapter, ⅝″ 27 threads per inch (tpi) Unified Straight thread
  • Microphone

author: Roborov

description.text:
I made this spotting camera to be able to view a remote target. The camera uses a Pi camera module with a separate lens. The case could also be used to house a raspberry pi Zero, particularly if it needs to function on battery power occasionally.

I printed all of the pieces except for the camera face without support.
I designed my own support structure for the camera face. There are stl files with and without the support.
I tapped the camera board mount after printing, since I was afraid that such a fine thread would not print well (M12x0.5 Tap used is listed below)
The Raspberry Pi Zero was secured with #4 x 1/4" sheet metal screws.
The camera board and Lipo charger were secured with #2 x 1/4" sheet metal screws.

I think in bright sunlight it may need a filter

The design was created in OpenSCAD
I did not use support created from a slicer, I added support into the design file.
The frame has support over the USB opening and the switch opening.

Additional parts

Lipo charger / power board from Adafruit https://www.adafruit.com/product/2465
Slide switch for on/off https://www.adafruit.com/product/805
I recomend the Pi Zero W bundle w/ the camera board, and Pi case. You'll have to discard the case, but you get the short camera cable at no extra cost
https://www.adafruit.com/product/3414

I used this tap to create the threads for the lense Tap https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LJ3PPKM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Zoom lense https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NVA96ME/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Lipo battery similar to https://www.amazon.com/HOBBYTIGER-1200mAh-Battery-Batteries-Quadcopter/dp/B01HG7TYNI/ref=pd_sbs_21_6?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=TYZVQ43747CKF3TQXPBJ

#4 x 1/4 " wood or sheet metal screw like https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CEZSXIE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (or find them at True Value hardware if you are in the US).

#2 x 1/4" wood or sheet metal screw (for the lipo charger) like https://www.amazon.com/Screws-Phillips-Stainless-Self-Tapping-Quantity/dp/B01CEZSQU4/ref=pd_sim_328_2?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=3M56HNPGXSZA9AK6YC2R

With Pi Zero W attached LiPo Charger / Power board attached. The micro USB oriented to the back panel (toward the right in the photograph). The battery below the Pi Zero next to the power switch. The yellow cap holds the switch in place. The assembled camera

I broke the little handle from my Oster expresso machine, so i design one!
Like and share if you like it!

description.text:
Connect your hammock or other cord items with a lightweight printable item instead of a heavy and expensive (in comparison) carabiner. Print one for each side of the hammock.

Similar to the really nice / lightweight Hummingbird Hammock Button Link setup, but can be attached to existing whoopie slings without undoing them. Just thread them into the sling loop as seen in the photo to install. To use, simply loop the button through the whoopie sling loop and back into itself. The tension will cause the button to more firmly set. If tension is relieved, the button may come undone.

WARNING: Use at your own risk. Only set up a hammock as high as you're comfortable falling. This file is to be used at your own risk. If there's anything wrong with the model, your print or your installation, it can fail and cause injury.

remixed_from.author: AzzA
remixed_from.title: Z braces for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select, and Malyan M150 i3 3D printers.

title: LED Brace Covers for Azza's Z-Braces

description.text:
Not quite a remix, but more of an addition to.

I got tired of not seeing my build bed in the dark at night when checking on the prints before bed, so I did these up. I tried first with the snap-on types, but they just weren't to my liking, so I went with a full slide on version.

You'll need to print 4 more balls of your choosing from Azza's Z-Brace Thingi to hold this to your braces in the position you choose. These are designed for 8mm self-adhesize strip LEDs such as: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCMNDVY.

Additionally, each cover has a flat side and a cup for your balls to hold everything in place ... just so. This allows for two of these to be placed on your brace and tightened down in position perfectly and never move again until you choose to move them. Just insert your brace rods into the covers making sure the flat sides of each cover touch each other, and you've added a ball/nut combo to both top and bottom. Then simply apply your LED strip and adjust for effect. Total of 4 to print, 2 per side, plus balls.

These can be used with white (like I chose to use) or RGB strips. How you wire them up is entirely up to you, but if you choose the RGBs, do your homework on how to attached them to allow your controller to change the colors.

The raw Fusion360 file can be found and tinkered with here: http://a360.co/2tZztJg

I wired my white LEDs directly to my power supply so that when the PSU is on, the lights are on. Your Mileage May Vary. I do not support, nor am I to be held responsible for, your particular setup for the electric side of the house on this as that is entirely in your ball-park.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print standing on-end, flat end on the build-plate, ball cup at the top. You can print with the flat portion for the LED strips if you want, but the stacked build allows for a rough surface for the adhesive to really grab onto. If you glass the flat where the LED's stick, your strips may not hold after a time.

description.text: I created this key cap for a small project I'm working on that uses four Cherry MX switches in a row (4 key 555 timer piano). The other typewriter keys available fit great but were a bit more difficult to print. I added a fillet to the base of they key in order to create a stronger part, and to provide some support to the part as the smaller details are formed.

No

Resolution:

.32

20%

Notes:

Print with a cool hotend temperature. A high temperature hotend will cause the cross part to ooze and over extrude; this will ruin the fit.

On my particular Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2 (Monoprice Maker Select V2) with Hatchbox PLA I am running temps between 200 and 208 for this part. 205 seems to give good layer adhesion and minimal oozing. Your printer may be different, but print it as cool as you can without getting layer adhesion issues.

title: Ryobi 18V String Trimmer - Brush Cutter Attachment

description.text:
UDATE - 8/5/2017: - Upped the temperature to 210 for PLA. This seemed to do the trick. The blade only lasted about 30 minutes, BUT...this time, I was clearing brush in an area with lots of rocks, some concrete, and a cedar fence. The estimated count was ~5 firm bumps on the cedar fence, ~10 rocks (be careful of flying rocks, BTW), and 3 really bad bashes against the concrete; it was a sloped hill, and I couldn't see the chunks of concrete buried underneath the brush. There were some gouges in the plastic where it ate the impact without breaking. If you want to see, find the picture with the dirty yellow plastic.

UPDATE - 7/22/2017: - By request, uploading V7 with blades that are 2 cm longer. Further updates, anything but the first two (V6 and V7) are on here by request.

UPDATE - 7/19/2017: - https://youtu.be/5b0-aYOpFo8

Let's begin with: USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!!!!

This is version 6 of my brush cutter. It attaches to a Ryobi 18V String Trimmer (THIS ONE). It is designed to cut down thicker brush that may grow in your yard, and this version seems to be able to handle large weeds about the diameter of my pinky finger (average adult male). I did break it when I hit the cedar fence, but it's not meant to take that amount of force.
PRINTING

I recommend printing this at 100% infill. As long as you don't abuse it, it probably won't break. You can then sharpen it by sanding it if it starts getting dull. Also, 100% infill adds to the rigidity of the design, and you want that.

BONUS: Here's a video of Version 5, which definitely broke: https://youtu.be/4e7GXS0hwms
The version 6 brush cutter blades are twice as thick, and it tore through those weeds.

Older Updates
7/18/2017: After several tests, I think the design is okay, but PLA is the wrong material for this. They all run for about 10 minutes before breaking. I have some PETG and ABS (both of which I've never printed in), and I'll be testing this print in both of those. If I'm not happy with those, I'll try nylon filament. Let me know if you guys have any other ideas.

remixed_from.author: AnyWorldGames
remixed_from.title: i3 Frame Mounting System - Major Mod to Duplicator Style

description.text:
I really like the idea of adjustable frame leveling feet with vibration dampeners, but when I tried using TyphonPS's Z-Braces, my extruder kept hitting the braces on the higher Z-Levels. I thought about using Azza's Z-Braces by themselves, but ultimately I decided to go with AnyWorldGames' entire frame rebuild that remixes Azza's Z-Brace into the design as a part of the rebuild. However, there were no leveling feet for it. Thus, here it is.

You'll need to use the support feet from TyphonPS's Thingi (I've included a modified STL for this, but you can use the one from his Thingi as well without issue. Print 6 total, pad side down, 100% infill or the threads will break under load with PLA). You'll also need to pickup some O-Rings, the exact type are listed in TyphonPS's Thingi.

After printing the feet, you can then print off the rest of included files. I suggest you start with a good level support table under the printer before leveling using the feet.

To level using the feet, start with all of the feet threaded all the way in. Then hang a magnetic level under your top frame and adjust the center tower first (you'll need to loosen your Z-Braces if you've previously set them) by threading the feet out of the supports (They are Right-Hand Threads, so turn the feet to the left to raise the machine, right to lower). Then place the level across the rear Y-Axis Guide Rods and level the rear of the machine, then repeat for the front. After setting, verify all three spots again. After doing this, you can simply use the magnetic level on the uprights of the tower side fronts to level your Z-Braces and lock them in place without having to worry about using a square.

The raw Fusion360 files can be downloaded and tinkered with here:

  • Back: http://a360.co/2t6sI5I
  • Front Left: http://a360.co/2upGiFa
  • Front Right: http://a360.co/2u0bQPa
  • Tower: http://a360.co/2thpK2v

These Feet will work for either AnyWorldGames' frame rebuild or Azza's Z-Braces alone.

title: Brake Hose Clamp for Fox Float Fork

description.text:
My eBay Fox Float 32 fork didn't come with a brake hose clamp. I got tired of using a cable tie so I printed this clamp to hold the hydraulic brake hose in place.

There's an indentation in the forks to sandwich a rubber pad behind the hose and keep it from sliding up/down through the clamp. I cut a small chunk of rubber out of an old bike tire. (5x8mm) A glob of hot glue would probably work just as well.

Screw is an M3x12mm.

description.text:
Green ranger helmet parts are scaled to print on a 300x300mm print area. Except for the 1 piece helmet that is sized for a 200x200mm print surface and is the original file just scaled down. I cut the top ring in half for printing on smaller printers, it seems everything can be printed on a Prusa i3 MKS or similar sized bed.

Probably not the best job of slicing it up into pieces to print, I may try another pass at it, I printed this for a friend who is into the Green Ranger and needed a helmet.

The picture of it together, all the parts are being held together with Painters Tape, so you see the cuts, the Helmet is not finished in these pictures

Este es un robot para el trabajo educativo, y tiene el propósito de ayudante casero para barrer y aspirar el piso en una vivienda,

Paso 1. diseño de piezas para su montaje; se diseñó en tinkercad la pieza del frente y otra pieza que va unida a la de enfrente en la parte superior donde se aloja la matriz de leds. en la de enfrente van los ultrasonidos

Paso 2. se realiza el corte de las piezas; las piezas de la base se consiguió en el comercio, se agrego la pieza del frente y otra que va unida en la parte superior, adicional a estas piezas se realizaron otras piezas con material reciclado de aluminio para el soporte del banco de baterías, el servomotor del brazo, la base de la placa de arduino se monto sobre soportes de placa de pc reciclados.

Paso 3. Se realiza el montaje de la electrónica en la base del carro robótico, se prueban los elementos para su funcionamiento con los ejemplos de Facilino, y se realizan las conexiones según el diseño en Fritzing. se realizo el video de los ejemplos cuyo funcionamiento es visible. se modifico el uso de los servomotores de rotación por motores DC y para su control se uso el Driver L298N

http://fritzing.org/projects/barrebot-v-10

Paso 4. Se utiliza la aplicación de Arduino y de APP Inventor para generar el código de la aplicación Barrebot. se puso a funcionar el cambio de caras, el acceso al Bluetooth el acceso al acelerómetro, en el centro a las direcciones del los motores del carro, y a subir y a bajar la escoba con el servo. no se ha activado el seguilineas ni el ultrasonido aun tratare de hacerlo antes del vencimiento del examen. en algun momento pense que fallaba el sistema pero era solo falta de energía en las baterías por eso el video aparece con energía conectada a la red y el cable de USB conectado al Arduino, el sistema consume mucha energía, lo cual es un parámetro a tener en cuenta para el diseño de la barredora rea. subo los códigos utilizados

pude trabajar el acelerómetro, pero para el movimiento autónomo no pude realizar el seguilineas ya que los motores DC se mueven con diferente fuerza y no funciona bien, trate de que barriera su recorrido pero parece mas un baile loco, por los mismos motores.

BARREBOT_V_1.0

/
Barrebot v 1.0
El proposito de este ejercicio es tener las bases necesarias para hacer un robot ayundante
domestico, poder calcular las necesidades de fuerza y demas parametros necesarios para que
realice su labor en solitario
/

include

Servo servo;

include

int _bt_cmd=0;

/ Global variables /
SoftwareSerial blueToothSerial(2,4);

/ Function declaration /
void LEDMatrix_init(int cs, int din, int clk);
void writeRow(int cs, int din, int clk, int row, int data);
void maxAll (int cs, int din, int clk, int reg, int col);
void putByte (int din, int clk, int data);
void happy(int cs, int din, int clk);
void angry(int cs, int din, int clk);
void sad(int cs, int din, int clk);
void heart(int cs, int din, int clk);

int IN3 = 6;
int IN4 = 5;
int IN1 = 8;
int IN2 = 9;

void setup()
{

//Attach servo to pin 3
servo.attach(3);

//Set pins for bluetooth transmission/reception
pinMode(2,INPUT);
pinMode(4, OUTPUT);
blueToothSerial.begin(9600);
blueToothSerial.flush();

//Set LED Matrix pins
pinMode(10,OUTPUT);
pinMode(12,OUTPUT);
pinMode(11,OUTPUT);

//Initialize LED Matrix
maxAll(10,12,11,11,7);
maxAll(10,12,11,9,0);
maxAll(10,12,11,12,1);
maxAll(10,12,11,15,0);
int i=0;
for (i = 1; i <= 8; i++)
maxAll(10,12,11,i,0);
maxAll(10,12,11,10,15);

pinMode (IN4, OUTPUT); // Input4 conectada al pin 5
pinMode (IN3, OUTPUT); // Input3 conectada al pin 6
pinMode (IN1, OUTPUT); // Input4 conectada al pin 8
pinMode (IN2, OUTPUT); // Input3 conectada al pin 9
}

void loop()
{
digitalWrite (IN4, LOW);
digitalWrite (IN3, LOW);
digitalWrite (IN1, LOW);
digitalWrite (IN2, LOW);

//Check received command
if (blueToothSerial.available()>0 || _bt_cmd>0)
{
int cmd=blueToothSerial.read();

  if ((cmd==2)||(_bt_cmd==2)){
        happy(10,12,11);

  }
   if ((cmd==3)||(_bt_cmd==3)){
        sad(10,12,11);
        delay(2000);
  }
  if ((cmd==4)||(_bt_cmd==4)){
        heart(10,12,11);

  }

  if ((cmd==5)||(_bt_cmd==5)){
        angry(10,12,11);

  }

 if ((cmd==21)||(_bt_cmd==21)){
        _bt_cmd=21;
       // Motor adelante
           digitalWrite (IN3, HIGH);
           digitalWrite (IN4, LOW); 
           digitalWrite (IN2, HIGH);
           digitalWrite (IN1, LOW);  

  }
 if ((cmd==22)||(_bt_cmd==22)){
        _bt_cmd=22;
       // Motor atras

           digitalWrite (IN3, LOW);
           digitalWrite (IN4, HIGH); 
           digitalWrite (IN2, LOW);
           digitalWrite (IN1, HIGH); 
         //  delay(100); 
  }
 if ((cmd==25)||(_bt_cmd==25)){
        _bt_cmd=25;
       // Motor PARA
           digitalWrite (IN4, LOW);
           digitalWrite (IN3, LOW); 
           digitalWrite (IN1, LOW);
           digitalWrite (IN2, LOW); 

  }
   if ((cmd==23)||(_bt_cmd==23)){
        _bt_cmd=23;
       // Motor derecha

           digitalWrite (IN4, HIGH);
           digitalWrite (IN3, LOW); 
           digitalWrite (IN1, LOW);
           digitalWrite (IN2, HIGH); 

  }
  if ((cmd==24)||(_bt_cmd==24)){
        _bt_cmd=24;
       // Motor izquierda

           digitalWrite (IN4, LOW);
           digitalWrite (IN3, HIGH); 
           digitalWrite (IN1, HIGH);
           digitalWrite (IN2, LOW); 

  }
  if ((cmd==34)||(_bt_cmd==34)){
        _bt_cmd=34;
       // Escoba abajo
        servo.write(45);

  }
  if ((cmd==32)||(_bt_cmd==32)){
        _bt_cmd=32;
       // Escoba arriba
        servo.write(135);

  }

}

}

/ Function definition /
void LEDMatrix_init(int cs, int din, int clk) {
maxAll(cs,din,clk,11,7);
maxAll(cs,din,clk,9,0);
maxAll(cs,din,clk,12,1);
maxAll(cs,din,clk,15,0);
int i=0;
for (i = 1; i <= 8; i++) {
maxAll(cs,din,clk,i, 0);
}
maxAll(cs,din,clk,10,15);
}

void writeRow(int cs, int din, int clk, int row, int data) {
digitalWrite(cs,LOW);
putByte(din,clk,row);
putByte(din,clk,data);
digitalWrite(cs,LOW);
digitalWrite(cs,HIGH);
}

void maxAll (int cs, int din, int clk, int reg, int col) {
digitalWrite(cs,LOW);
putByte(din,clk,reg);
putByte(din,clk,col);
digitalWrite(cs,LOW);
digitalWrite(cs,HIGH);
}

void putByte (int din, int clk, int data) {
byte i = 8;
byte mask;
while(i > 0) {
mask = 0x01 << (i - 1);
digitalWrite(clk,LOW);
if (data & mask){
digitalWrite(din,HIGH);
}
else{
digitalWrite(din,LOW);
}
digitalWrite(clk,HIGH);
--i;
}
}

void sad(int cs, int din, int clk) {
writeRow(cs,din,clk,1, 12);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,2, 24);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,3, 48);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,4, 48);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,5, 48);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,6, 48);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,7, 24);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,8, 12);
}

void angry(int cs, int din, int clk) {
writeRow(cs,din,clk,1, 2);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,2, 68);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,3, 36);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,4, 16);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,5, 16);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,6, 36);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,7, 68);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,8, 2);
}

void happy (int cs, int din, int clk) {
writeRow(cs,din,clk,1, 48);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,2, 24);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,3, 12);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,4, 12);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,5, 12);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,6, 12);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,7, 24);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,8, 48);
}

void heart(int cs, int din, int clk) {
writeRow(cs,din,clk,1, 12);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,2, 30);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,3, 62);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,4, 124);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,5, 124);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,6, 62);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,7, 30);
writeRow(cs,din,clk,8, 12);
}

title: Half Inch Post Holder-Closed Slotted Base

description.text: Slotted base half inch post holder. The holes running up along the body are intended to be tapped for 1/4-20 thumb screws to lock the post in place. The slot in the base is size for clearance to slide along a 1/4-20 screw mounted into a standard 1" x 1" spacing optical breadboard/table.

You'll need to run a 1/4-20 tap through the holes in the body. Holes oriented in this manner tend to sag and shrink so the tap will be a tight fit. This is intended in an effort to extend the life of the holes.

Intended to be mounted onto standard optical breadboards and isolation tables. As such, the slot is specced to freely move along a 1/4-20 screw. At about 2.5" long the slot is always within reach of a mounting hole on a standard 1" spaced breadboard.

The through hole on both versions is significantly oversized at 0.520" to compensate for surface roughness and shrinkage that occurs during printing with PLA. I'd recommend a test print of a single piece before attempting a batch.

author: Freds_Optix_Hardware

description.text:
Slotted bases intended to mate to standard 1/2" post holders for mounting optics and or detectors to optical tables. The slots in the base are sized for clearance to slide along 1/4-20 screws. You should use a washer to distribute the load when tightening down to the table to increase the life of the part. Slot radius is 1"

The center hole(s) are countersunk and required a 1/4-20 screw up through the bottom to attach to commercially available post holders. I've successfully printed both of these versions in PLA.

You may find you need to widen the center through holes depending on any shrinkage during the print.

This item can be paired with the 3" table clamp elsewhere in my things.

print_settings.Notes:: It's holding up styrofoam that is being shot with a toy that fires toothpicks, strength isn't an issue

description.text:
A guy I know bought a little toy crossbow that shoots toothpicks, this sounded so fun to me I had to design a tiny target stand to fit the crossbows size.

The styrofoam is a 4" X 4" (or 100mm X 100mm for my metric makers). I used a relatively thick post for strength, so the styrofoam has to be pretty thick, I cut my piece off a block that came along as support for a printer I bought.

I printed 4" photos of targets and attached them with a glue stick. You could just do a search for target images, but I uploaded the ones I made just so you can save an extra step.

Obviously, this doesn't require crazy thickness or fill, but I did make it with 80% fill because it made only 3 minutes difference in time. The target holding rods are fairly thick, not that it needs it, just because I'd rather over build than have them break off. Maybe I'll update it with detachable rods, or adapt a household item. :)

I also want to point out that the unit is symmetrical so I only did 1, then just printed it twice.

description.text:

also won't prevent you manually folding the antenna down either, it'll easily slide up so you can fold it.

to put it on, you need to remove the first rod.
you may also need to grind a tiny bit more where the 2 set screws hit on the first rod, to make the set screws be flush with the base.

final fitting should be slightly loose, easily slide-able up and down.

title: Sodastream Glass Bottle Anti-Blow Out Preventer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
made this adapter to help prevent blow-outs while filling the threaded glass bottles, on my penguin style filler.

it seems it was made for the hex style glass bottles, rather than the threaded ones, so quite often when using the threaded ones, it buckles the seal and explodes the water/co2 all over.
since using this ring on the threaded bottles, it hasn't exploded/buckled once.
the cap should be even with the top of the glass bottle, as it is just for adding extra support, and not for creating an air-tight seal.

when using, the thick part goes towards the base of the glass bottle, or the thin side goes upwards, towards the seal.

description.text:
This is a LED ring light adapter that takes 40mm 12 LED ring lights (For example https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-2pcs-White-Angel-Headlight/dp/B00NPZ8W48) and attaches to the 12mm shaft of an Andonstar 2MP USB microscope.

The lid lets you insall a diffuser out of paper or diffuser material from an broken LCD monitor (Cut two concentric rings 40mm outside and 12mm inside)

Designed it for my pick and place machine, but turns out to be useful for general microscope use. The built in ring light is too close and makes it difficult to read chip markings.

Printing the mount: Orient the model so the base (the opening for the LED ring light) is down. You will probably need supports "touching the buildplate only". I also used a raft on this part to keep things nice and clean. Everything touching the raft and support will be covered by the lid.

Printing the lid: Flip the lid so the flat side is down (Fusion exports it in the orientation of the original assembly)

description.text:
A pivoting bowden tube filament guide.

The 1.75mm guide expects the bowden tube to be 4mm outer diameter and the 3mm guide expects it to be 6mm.

Mounts with two M3 screws onto whatever you like, so it should be easy to mount on aluminum extrusions or a printed mount adapter.

Print it, stuff a ptfe tube in there (or don't, whatevs), and bolt it on. The tube fit is tight, I didn't want it pulling through. I only got about 3mm into mine and I don't think it's coming out in one piece, which is fine.

Tested with a Prusa i3 (mount adapter https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2438332 ) and it gives me a smooth kink free feed even when the extruder is at the top of the Z axis.

author: Awacs

title: Wanhao D7 Stackable Resin Vat Holder

description.text:
This is a quick stackable vat holder for the Wanhao D7 Resin DLP printer.

Using this to elevate your vat, it should be easier to clean out the FEP and stack your resin vats especially if you are using multiple vats for multiple resins. It should also be easy to cut a piece of opaque cardstock to cover your vat and reduce any light from getting to your resin.

As a bonus, if you are using clear resin like we do, having a desk light over the vat with a piece of white paper beneath will allow you to quickly spot and filter our any cured impurities in your resin vat.

There are 2 versions of the STLs in here - one for a whole vat holder which you can print at one shot if your print bed allows for it, and 4 other files where the vat holder has been segmented into quarters that connect via" jigsaw" joints that you can glue together when complete. Support may be needed to hold up the little notches in the bottom unless your printer can handle bridging well. :)

Have fun with this and love to see this in the wild helping all you folks! =)

Support us on Patreon - https://www.patreon.com/FunbieStudios

title: iPhone 7 Case "Regular"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had a request to remix my iPhone bumper case into a full case with a back so here it is. The back has openings for your camera and flash and protrudes just far enough to protect the camera from scrapes.
You shouldn't need to clean up the print as it comes off very clean. The attached video is from the bumper case I made but it's the same except for the added back.
The other benefit of this case is that it fits both the portrait and landscape stands I made for that bumper case;-

Portrait Car and desk stand:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431699

Landscape Car and desk stand:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431698

The original iPhone bumper can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431697

Make sure you read the "post printing" section before putting it on your phone.

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Prints best with the back of the case on the bottom.

I now mainly use Simplyfy3D to slice for three main reasons;-

  1. the supports come away beautifully and
  2. for items that rely on tight tolerances (like this case!) it prints the most accurate that I've used and
  3. You can specify different print settings in a print so for sections with detail you can reduce layer height and for uniform sections you can increase it and get great looking prints done fast!

I suggest printing with 4 perimeters and 25% infill as there's only a handful of grams of plastic in this so don't skimp.

I suggest printing this in an improved PLA (see below) or other filament that's strong and tough.

Beware: Not all PLA's are made equal.

Most of my prototypes and a good proportion of final prints are with an 'improved' PLA from Esun called PLA Plus (sometimes called pro) and it's tough and definitely not brittle and it's really cheap too. Some other moderately priced improved PLA's I've used are Filamentum, Prusa Brand & Colorfabb Economy PLA.

I haven't tried Hatchbox, Matterhackers, Taulman InPLA and Filaform Pro PLA but I hear some good things about them.

I also use a few better quality name brand PLA's for special one off jobs like phone cases and these are quite a bit better than the Esun though up to triple the price... though bare in mind this print in the pricey filament would still only cost a couple of bucks.

For the best looking prints with a fair bit better toughness than the Esun I use either Polymaker PolyMax PLA or ColorFabb PLA PHA. If excellent toughness and strength is a priority then the Polymaker PC Max polycarbonate is the one I'll always reach for and the finish is still good too.

It has a nice gentle chamfer so there shouldn't be any need to clean up the print if you print it as is on its back. Just remember that although your PLA might be tough it's normally not as flexible as the rubber cases you might be used to... so take a bit more care getting it on.
It's designed to fit in bottom first, sliding in and then gently easing the top in until it snaps into place. Take a look at the end of the bumper video (at 2:40) below to see how it's done.

This is from my bumper case but if you look close to the end you'll see me demonstrate how to put the case on your phone

English:
This is the "Bubbleblast", a machine which produces bubbles - cool, isn't it?
To get this thing working, you have to attach a small geared DC-motor to the wheel, clamp it on the motor-mount at the bassin and add a radial-fan to blow out the bubbles. The fan and the motor are controlled by an arduino nano, using PWM for the speedcontrol.

Thanks to heinzdrei for his bicycle-bubble-machine (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:950452). From his machine, I used the bubblewheel. I did a few changes, to fit it on a M3-screw, which is coupled to the 3mm shaft of the geared motor.

Deutsch:
Das ist die "BubbleBlast", eine Maschine die Seifenblasen produziert, cool oder?
Um das ganze ans Laufen zu bekommen braucht ihr noch einen kleinen Getriebemotor, den man einfach auf die Halterung am Becken anbringen kann und einen Radiallüfter um die Seifenblasen auszublasen. Den Lüfter und den Motor kann man mit einem Arduino Nano in der Geschwindigkeit einstllen, dazu habe ich zwei Potis auf Analogeingänge gelegt und das Signal als PWM an die Transistoren und somit die Motoren wieder ausgegeben.

https://youtu.be/yH7yStcukpU

Geared DC-Motor:
https://goo.gl/UKgJ7A

author: CrazyJ

description.text: I'm working on a project to mount my Chumby One in a new case. I've been planning this for quite some time and the Chumby hasn't been on in a very long time. Getting my maker bot and doing a couple projects has inspired me to get working on my Chumby mod. Even though they aren't making the hardware anymore, this is sure to be awesome. I'm going to post parts as I make them and keep updating the progress.

• Print it...it warped quite a bit for me, but it's flexible enough for this to not really matter.

  • Drill out the holes on the mouting legs. They didn't print out quite bit enough for me to reuse the original mounting screws, so I drilled them out.

  • I also had to enlarge one of the holes on the board itself. Don't worry, there is plenty of clearance.

  • Mount the holder to your case. There are 4 mounting holes to use.

  • Use the screws from your Chumby to attach the board.

description.text:
A dice tower for all your gaming needs! Need to be sure that your dice rolls are random? Running out of table space? Want to show your friends that you have a 3D printer? Then you need this dice tower!

The tower prints in 4 parts: (1) Tower, (1) Tower Wall, (2) Trays (you could get away without the trays and still get the randomization)

The cutouts are for 8mm x 3mm rare earth magnets. Glue in the magnets and the tower, walls and trays will stay together, but still allow it to come apart so you can take it with you!

title: [email protected] vawt mould making wind turbine blades
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Hi,these are my 3d printable moulds for making vawt wind turbine blades,the centre women images are to be printed then the outside to be made into a silicon rubber mould,the centres of the images to be packed with moulding plasticine,i use this type because it releases easier, then remove the plasticine once the silicon two part mould has dried, pour a colour mix plastic quick dry plastic casting polyurethane into the mould images,the inside will be clear around the images,the outside casts will be cast in clear plastic, i have split the outside casts to make these pieces easier to make into a silicon mould two piece mould,the outside blade bracket that holds the blades,will fit the inside diameter of the outside casts of the inside diameter when the plastic pour has set.

title: iPhone 7 Case "box of apples"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had a request to remix my iPhone bumper case into a full case with a back so here is my apple logo version. I designed it this way so that the case back protects the back while all the cutout apples allows it to thermo-regulate better than a standard case. The back also has openings for your camera and flash and protrudes just far enough to protect the camera from scrapes.
You shouldn't need to clean up the print as it comes off very clean. The attached video is from the bumper case I made but it's the same except for the added back.
The other benefit of this case is that it fits both the portrait and landscape stands I made for that bumper case;-

Portrait Car and desk stand:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431699

Landscape Car and desk stand:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431698

The original iPhone bumper can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431697

Make sure you read the "post printing" section before putting it on your phone.

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Prints best with the back of the case on the bottom.

I now mainly use Simplyfy3D to slice for three main reasons;-

  1. the supports come away beautifully and
  2. for items that rely on tight tolerances (like this case!) it prints the most accurate that I've used and
  3. You can specify different print settings in a print so for sections with detail you can reduce layer height and for uniform sections you can increase it and get great looking prints done fast!

I suggest printing with 4 perimeters and 25% infill as there's only a handful of grams of plastic in this so don't skimp.

I suggest printing this in an improved PLA (see below) or other filament that's strong and tough.

Beware: Not all PLA's are made equal.

Most of my prototypes and a good proportion of final prints are with an 'improved' PLA from Esun called PLA Plus (sometimes called pro) and it's tough and definitely not brittle and it's really cheap too. Some other moderately priced improved PLA's I've used are Filamentum, Prusa Brand & Colorfabb Economy PLA.

I haven't tried Hatchbox, Matterhackers, Taulman InPLA and Filaform Pro PLA but I hear some good things about them.

I also use a few better quality name brand PLA's for special one off jobs like phone cases and these are quite a bit better than the Esun though up to triple the price... though bare in mind this print in the pricey filament would still only cost a couple of bucks.

For the best looking prints with a fair bit better toughness than the Esun I use either Polymaker PolyMax PLA or ColorFabb PLA PHA. If excellent toughness and strength is a priority then the Polymaker PC Max polycarbonate is the one I'll always reach for and the finish is still good too.

It has a nice gentle chamfer so there shouldn't be any need to clean up the print if you print it as is on its back. Just remember that although your PLA might be tough it's normally not as flexible as the rubber cases you might be used to... so take a bit more care getting it on.
It's designed to fit in bottom first, sliding in and then gently easing the top in until it snaps into place. Take a look at the end of the bumper video (at 2:40) below to see how it's done.

This is from my bumper case but if you look close to the end (@ 2:40) you'll see me demonstrate how to put the case on your phone

--- Français (English below) ---

Voici deux variantes d'un chariot conçu pour se déplacer le long d'un profilé aluminium 20x20 de type V-Slot. Les déplacements sont pilotés par une courroie GT2 dont la tension est réglée par le tendeur. La liaison avec les tiges reliées à l'effecteur est assurée par deux aimants fraisés distants de 45mm entre axes.
L'effecteur magnétique d'entre-axe 45mm associé à ces chariots se trouve ici : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024371

J'ai conçu deux versions de ce chariot pour vérifier s'il y a une différence de qualité d'impression entre les deux modèles. Je suppose que la variante avec les aimants au centre de du chariot offre le meilleur résultat. En effet, les tiges qui relient le chariot à l'effecteur exercent des contraintes sur le chariot, les repoussant vers l'extérieur de l'imprimante. Plus les points d’application des forces (donc les aimants) sont éloignés du centre du chariot et plus le bras de levier est important. Par conséquent, les mouvements indésirables devraient être amplifiés avec le modèle de chariot possédant les fixations d'aimants en haut. Reste à voir si les contraintes exercées par les tiges sont suffisantes pour affecter la qualité d'impression... Sinon l'avantage de déporter les aimants vers le haut est que l'on gagne 4cm de hauteur d'impression.
N'hésitez pas à me faire vos retours d’expérience en postant un commentaire.

NB : Les supports matériels nécessaires sont inclus dans le design, inutile d'activer cette fonctionnalité du slicer.

L'assemblage d'un chariot compte deux pièces imprimées :

  • un chariot
  • un tendeur

Quincaillerie pour un chariot :

  • 3x Roues :
    • 1x roue type Solid V Wheel (pneu + 2 roulements 625ZZ + rondelle de précision m5)
    • 1x Vis M5x25 (pour fixer la roue)
    • 1x rondelle courte M5
  • 1x Réglage de butée Home :
    • 1x Vis M3x20
    • 2x Ecrou M3
  • 1x Tendeur de courroie :
    • 1x Vis M3x25
    • 1x Rondelle courte M3
    • 1x Ecrou M3
  • 1x Serrage sur profilé alu 20x20
    • 1x Vis M3x25
    • 1x Ecrou M3
  • 2x Aimants fraisés D12 d4 e4.75

Préparation

  1. Imprimez et nettoyez les deux pièces
  2. Supprimez les supports d'impression du chariot
  3. Vérifiez que tout s’emboîte correctement

Assemblage

Inutile de rentrer dans une longue et ennuyeuse description, ça se monte comme sur la photo :)

--- English ---

Here are two variants of a carriage adapted to slide along a 20x20 V-Slot type aluminium profile. The moves are controlled by a GT2 belt whose tension is adjusted by the tensioner. The connection with the rods connected to the effector is provided by two countersunk magnets spaced by 45mm between axes.

The displacement is controlled by a GT2 belt whose tension is adjusted by the tensioner. The connection with the rods connected to the end effector is provided by two spaced countersunk magnets 45mm between axes.
The magnetic effector with 45mm between-axle associated with these carriage can be found here : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024371

I designed two versions of the carrier to test if there is a difference in print quality between the two models. I guess the variant with magnets on the centre of the carrier provides the best result. Indeed, the rods which connect the carriage to the effector exert constraints on the carriage, pushing them outwardly of the printer. More the points of application of forces (thus the magnets) are away from the centre of the carriage, and more the lever arm is important. Therefore, undesirable movements should be amplified with the carriage model having the magnet mountings on the top. It remains to see if the stresses exerted by the rods are sufficient to affect the print quality. . . Otherwise the advantage to deport the magnets up is that we gain 4cm print height.
Do not hesitate to make me your feedback by posting a comment.

NB: All necessary materials support are included in the design, no need to activate this feature in the slicer.

The assembly of a carriage has two printed parts :

  • a carriage
  • a tensioner

Hardware for one carriage :

  • 3x Wheels:
    • 1x wheel Wheel Type Solid V (tire + 2 x 625ZZ bearing + 1x M5 precision washer)
      • 1x M5x25 screws (to fix the wheel)
      • 1x M5 short washer
  • 1x Home end stop adjustment screw :
    • 1x M3x20 screw
    • 2x M3 Nut
  • 1x Belt tensioner :
    • 1x M3x25 screw
    • 1x M3 short Washer
    • 1x M3 nut
  • 1x Tightening on aluminium profile 20x20
    • 1x M3x25 screw
    • 1x M3 nut
  • 2x countersunk D12 Magnets d4 e4.75

Preparation

  1. Print and clean the two parts
  2. Remove the print support material
  3. Make sure all fits correctly

Assembly

No need to go into a long and boring description, it's mounted as show on the picture. :)

print_settings.Notes:: For the best looking prints with a fair bit better toughness than the Esun I use either Polymaker PolyMax PLA or ColorFabb PLA PHA. If excellent toughness and strength is a priority then the Polymaker PC Max polycarbonate is the one I'll always reach for and the finish is still good too.

title: iPhone 7 Case "dotty"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had a request to remix my iPhone bumper case into a full case with a back so here is my dotty version. I designed it this way so that the case back protects the back while all the cutout dots allows it to thermo-regulate better than a standard case. The back also has openings for your camera and flash and protrudes just far enough to protect the camera from scrapes.
You shouldn't need to clean up the print as it comes off very clean. The attached video is from the bumper case I made but it's the same except for the added back.
The other benefit of this case is that it fits both the portrait and landscape stands I made for that bumper case;-

Portrait Car and desk stand:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431699

Landscape Car and desk stand:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431698

The original iPhone bumper can be found here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2431697

Make sure you read the "post printing" section before putting it on your phone.

You can check out my other designs here:-
https://www.thingiverse.com/ScottyMakesStuff/designs

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print this in the orientation supplied.

I now mainly use Simplyfy3D to slice for three main reasons;-

  1. the supports come away beautifully and
  2. for items that rely on tight tolerances (like this case!) it prints the most accurate that I've used and
  3. You can specify different print settings in a print so for sections with detail you can reduce layer height and for uniform sections you can increase it and get great looking prints done fast!

I suggest printing with 4 perimeters and 25% infill as there's only a handful of grams of plastic in this so don't skimp.

I suggest printing this in an improved PLA (see below) or other filament that's strong and tough.

Beware: Not all PLA's are made equal.

Most of my prototypes and a good proportion of final prints are with an 'improved' PLA from Esun called PLA Plus (sometimes called pro) and it's tough and definitely not brittle and it's really cheap too. Some other moderately priced improved PLA's I've used are Filamentum, Prusa Brand & Colorfabb Economy PLA.

I haven't tried Hatchbox, Matterhackers, Taulman InPLA and Filaform Pro PLA but I hear some good things about them.

I also use a few better quality name brand PLA's for special one off jobs like phone cases and these are quite a bit better than the Esun though up to triple the price... though bare in mind this print in the pricey filament would still only cost a couple of bucks.

For the best looking prints with a fair bit better toughness than the Esun I use either Polymaker PolyMax PLA or ColorFabb PLA PHA. If excellent toughness and strength is a priority then the Polymaker PC Max polycarbonate is the one I'll always reach for and the finish is still good too.

It has a nice gentle chamfer so there shouldn't be any need to clean up the print if you print it as is on its back. Just remember that although your PLA might be tough it's normally not as flexible as the rubber cases you might be used to... so take a bit more care getting it on.
It's designed to fit in bottom first, sliding in and then gently easing the top in until it snaps into place. Take a look at the end of the bumper video (at 2:40) below to see how it's done.

This is from my bumper case but if you look close to the end (@ 2:40) you'll see me demonstrate how to put the case on your phone

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in HobbyKing transparent PLA in order to ensure all the sizes were right. I'll see how this degrades over time, if at all.

description.text:
The skimmer baskets in our pool were beginning to perish, with the edges becoming very brittle and easily snapping with minimal force. Looking online it seems that these are quite pricey to replace, at around £20 each. I'm not suggesting it's a lot cheaper to print, after taking the time into consideration, but it seems that there's an opportunity to improve on the original. Therefore, instead of the edges being wafer thin, I've sized them at 2mm, as I've seen others do. The square holes around the edge are 4mm square(ish). Rather than tussle with a square pattern around the bottom, I opted for a concentric circle design. Holes are made around the upper basket to take a handle.

After a few attempts, I finally got the right strength for the handle, which acts as both a lifting aid and also a method to twist the basket into the locking mechanism of the skimmer housing below.

The rim around the top is designed to snap onto the top of the basket. This adds a lot of rigidity to the final object. It does take some force to snap on, and is probably my favorite part of the design.

If you want to adjust the design, be my guest:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/faf66a3f1ae01df9a806c298/v/1add465ac4ce707ee0a2204d

Printer:

E3D Bigbox

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You need a reasonably large printer for this. The outer diameter of the basket lid is the largest, at 180mm diameter. The main basket stands 126.5mm high. If you can print those dimensions, you'll be fine.

As always, getting the first layer right is probably the toughest. You might want a lower speed for this layer to get everything down smooth. This is not a short print, but the end result is worth it I think.

When printing the handle, you'll need to add some support for the ends of the cross piece. Normally, support generation, if automated, will then create a ton more support material around the main handle, which isn't needed. The design is such that you only need the support for the end "pegs".

I printed this in HobbyKing transparent PLA in order to ensure all the sizes were right. I'll see how this degrades over time, if at all.

comments.text: Hi there, i pretty sure PLA decomposes relatively fast when submerged in water (which is relatively easy to understand since its just lactic acid thrown together, bacteria eat that stuff). A friend printed something for an aquarium and it went unusable after 3 months. I suggest ABS for stuff like this :)

comments.text: 3 months!. I'll definitely keep an eye on it. Thanks for the input.

I created a tea light shade, to experiment with InkScape Voronoi extension.

The shade can be lift to access the candle.

I'm not sure it's a good idea to put a candle in a PLA box. The plastic might melt. I will have to experiment with it.

WARNING: Please, use a led candle light. If you really want to experiment with a real candle, do not leave it unattended.

[2017-07-19]: Increased the clearance to fit the box on the base. It was too tight.

[2017-07-29]: Fix the OpenSCAD file to work better with the Thingiverse Customizer tool.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Base:
The base is upside down. There is quite large bridging over the candle hole. My printer handled it pretty well. If you have issues with bridging, you might want to enable supports for that hole.

Box:
The shade box has very little surface contact with the bed. I gave it a try without brim or raft. It worked without problem. Although, the box was a 15 hours print at 0.1mm layer height. You might want to use brim to avoid issues. I also noticed some strange over-extrusion patterns inside the box. I believe those could be reduce by printing it at a 45 degree angle, which would use both X and Y motors to print the lines (using an i3 printer). That's what my printer do to print surfaces.

I made the Voronoi patterns using InkScape and dnewman's extension:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036

  1. In InkScape, make a new document 100mm x 100mm.
  2. Draw a small dot using the ellipse tool.
  3. Copy / Paste the dot at random location in the document.
  4. Create the Voronoi pattern:
    • Select all
    • Extensions > Generate from Path > Voronoi Diagram...
  5. Select and delete all the dots.
  6. Select the Voronoi pattern, ungroup it (Object > Ungroup).
  7. Change the stroke size. I choose 5mm.
  8. Make polygons from the lines (Path > Stroke to path)
  9. Merge the polygons (Path > Union)
  10. Remove excess
    • Create a square using the square tool
    • Select the square and change its properties at the top (X: 0, Y:0, W: 100mm, H: 100mm)
    • Select all (Ctrl+A), trim (Path > Intersect)
  11. Export as OpenSCAD file using dnewman extension (Extensions > Generate from Path > Paths to OpenSCAD...)
  12. Open the generated file and extract the polygons.

This is a pony cookie cutter based on a hopefully recognizable character. It is based on a PNG artwork commissioned for this purpose (stated up front that it would be posted as a cookie-cutter to Thingiverse under a Creative Commons license) from Arsh Darksbane - http://arshnessdreaming.deviantart.com/

I have not worked out yet the best combination of holes to allow easy removal of the material without leaving unsightly blobs, so there are no holes in the files for the moment.
You should probably open the SCAD file and add some holes (or you can drill them afterwards, as I did).
The STL file is the one I used to print the one in the photograph.
To use the SCAD file you will need to download the Pinkie*.dxf files into the same folder.
The v2 version has been printed, but not yet tested. In an attempt to resolve the issue of where to place the holes, I used a flat union of the original design and cut it out of the stl, then added back in bracing (the uploaded file contains two extra braces missing from my print, added due to a bend point obvious in the printed result) so that hopefully any swell from thicker dough will at least be in the shape of the pony. It is also deeper on both the impression, and the cutting edge - possibly too deep, again this is untested. I will update again after testing it.

title: Marlin 1.1.4 pour DiscoEasy200 + afficheur couche en cours + tuto pour installation

description.text:
Bonjour à tous,
Voici l’évolution stable du Marlin 1.1.4 pour DiscoEasy 200
Il est paramétré pour une DiscoEasy200 sortie d’usine avec écran.
Il n’y a pas besoin de re-cabler quoi que ce soit cette fois (Merci Jey !)

Les options activées :

  • Auto bed leveling bilinéaire (5ptsx5pts) avec subdivision 3
  • Affichage couche en cours (déjà présent dans certaine RC8 custom)
  • Ecran reprap full graphic
  • Le changement de filament hors pièce avec extrusion avant reprise (super pratique pour les changements de couleur)

Les options intéressantes à dé-commenter :

  • Les fonctions UBL de l’auto bed leveling
  • La gestion du sensor fin de fil
  • Le M150 pour transformer votre box en discothèque
  • Et bien d’autre
    Amusez-vous bien à torturer le petit dernier de Marlin et surtout, n’hésitez pas à poser des questions et à partager vos évolutions…
    Open source quoi…

PS: Afin d'accompagner les débutants, j'ai glissé un petit tuto au format PDF pour faciliter l'installation du firmware sur la belle...

PS2: si toute fois vous rencontrer un souci ou que vous souhaiteriez revenir en arriére sur le firmware dagoma, il suffit de repasser par dagoma app comme a votre habitude et reflasher le fichier.hex d'origine.

----------Modif suite à la demande de Tobit---------
Lors du changement de fil le plateau recul et bloque l'acces à l'extruder.
Pour ceux qui comme lui souhaiterai inverser la position du plateau et l’emmener vers l'avant il faut apporter une petite modif dans l'onglet configuration_adv.h:

rechercher (avec Ctrl + f ca va plus vite) la ligne suivante:

define PAUSE_PARK_Y_POS 10

remplacer "10" par "190"

cliquer sur fichier > enregistrer

et re-téléverser le firmware vers votre imprimante (c.f. tuto)

comments.text:
Bonjour a tous et merci pour ce super boulot
Debutant en impression 3D , J ai une DiscoEasy200 , qui fonctionnait bien , sauf que le Firmware Dagoma m enerve , car il n est pas possible de monter le Z par l ecran pour degager le travail ou essuyer ma buse baveuse . J ai change le Firmware par le tien et j y ai trouvé mon bonheur SAUF que le demarage de mes impressions se fait en l air . J ai testé avec mes fichiers anciens de ma SD , je me demande si ça vient de CURA et d un parametre a modifier dans le Start/End Gcode generé par Cura , ou un parametre du configuration.h , ou ailleurs ???
Merci pour ton aide
JLucP

comments.text:
Et bien, je ne partage pas ton avis. Les firmware signer dagoma sont vraiment perfectible. Ils sont a l'image de leur machine... mais ce n'est que mon avis.
Pour changer le nombre de point, Rdv dans configuration.h:
define GRID_MAX_POINTS_X 5
Remplace le 5 par 3, mais si tu veux revenir au firm dagoma, la liste des changements est longue et peut être vaudrait il mieux revenir en arrière afin de maîtriser un peu mieux ta machine et repasser sur un firm custom plus tard quand ta machine et toi seront prêt.. .

en fait le programme est prévu pour faire un +1 sur le compteur quand l'axe Z se déplace
il suffit que ton plateau ne soit pas parallèle à ton chariot ou que le G29 décale ton axe au delà de la surface de référence, et ça plante le truc.

comments.text:
pour ton petit 1, je te renvoi au site marlin car c'est franchement long a expliquer..... tout comme a configurer d’ailleurs.
http://marlinfw.org/docs/features/unified_bed_leveling.html
en gros, tu paramètre un maillage de ton plateau qui en quelques points de palpation lors du G29A va initialiser chaque point de ton plateau.
normalement, plus précis et plus rapide qu'un bed bilineaire. Le pourquoi je ne l'ai pas sélectionner par défaut, c'est que c'est une usine a gaz a configurer et que cela pourrait faire peur a beaucoup d'utilisateur et surtout que le résultat ne m'a pas bluffé.
Cela explique le choix du bilinéaire avec subdivision qui, malgré qu'il soit gourmand en ressource, passe bien avec les plateaux déformé de nos disco.
comments.author: Tobit

comments.text:
pour le calcul, c'est facile:
valeur du moteur / pas de la vis = valeur du firmware
la valeur moteur est 3200
donc avec les vis d'origine de 8mm pas metrique (1.25mm)
3200/1.25=2560 (valeur d'origine dagoma)

title: KLEIJNE Modular Fingerboard Ramp & Planter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KLEIJNE FINGERBOARD PLANTER

My submission for the Tinkercad x MyMiniFactory contest.

UPDATE
It won! :D The printer I won with it will probably go to my niece and nephew to further spread the virus ;)

It’ s a modular grinding bench and rail that you can stack up low or high by adding more or less mid sections. By alternating their orientation, a nice brick pattern is created, which gives the bench a genuine look. If you choose to add more mid sections, you can use the little pegs to connect the lower parts and up the height of the grind rail.

In the middle there is a space to plant something small, like garden cress, matching the fingerboard scale to give it something extra special.

The Fingerboard Planter also has growing potential (pun not intended but, tolerated), with an extra hole in the middle of the base, for mounting possible future add-ons like for instance a little fountain, 3D scanned bust of yourself or whatever you wish to stick on it. You can simply use one of the pegs as a base for that.

I wanted to give the rail a round look, but it should also be printable, and in the right orientation as well for sturdiness. Therefore I’ve flattened the sides, which gives you the opportunity to print it lying flat, without supports and with the most strength, to withstand aggressive landing and grinding.

Unfortunately my build plate is very small (I have a Monoprice Select Mini), so I could only print a micro fingerboard version (66%) as a prototype, but it should proof the concept just as well. I guess I could use that first prize ;) Also, my printer got a major clog, preventing me from making a nice print in more realistic and different colours, so unfortunately I have to post the quick 'n' dirty test run pics to submit in time. I will post better pictures as soon as possible.

I hope you like it, and please do build onto and remix the hell out of it. If you do, or just printed this one as is, I would love for you to share it.

Happy boarding!

Cheers, Baschz

This object was made in Tinkercad:
http://www.tinkercad.com/things/2fMDlzWCNCc

title: Sunglasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made some sunglasses because it's summer.

There are two versions available:

bruen44.stl:
This one is intended to be printed in one piece including the hinges. It actually works very well but the frame is a bit fragile and looks a bit rough with some materials when printed in this orientation. Pro-tip: print it upside down! It'll use much less support material this way.

pros:

  • prints in one piece
  • printable hinges!!!
  • ...
  • profit!

cons:

  • support removal can become critical to the structural integrity of the frame
  • looks less awesome
  • more fragile

bruen48*.stl:
This comes in three pieces which can be tucked together afterwards very easily.

pros:

  • much nicer finish on the front face
  • groves for the glasses come out more precise
  • side pieces can be printed in different colours/materials
  • it's possible to disassamble the glasses
  • you can get rid of the lettering easily
  • support removal more easy with almost no visible residues

cons:

  • several pieces
  • a bit more wobbly side pieces (but they're both quite wobbly to be honest)

I haven't put in real glasses/lenses yet; have to find some cheap ones to get them cut into the right shape.

The picture I've attached is from version #48 btw.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1-0,2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

44:
print it upside down with plenty of support for angles > 40° and 100% part cooling. Removal of support is a pretty unpleasant experience and you can destroy the frame quite easily while doing that.

48:
the frame comes in optimum printing orientation while the side pieces can be printed either the given way or upside down. The latter uses less support material but comes with the chance of worse overhangs. However I recommend support for angles > 40° anyway for the side pieces. The main-frame comes out good with support for angles > 70°. If you don't want the silly signature on the side frame, just mirror the "bruen48_buegl_r.stl" which is a blank one. Part cooling @ 100% recommended for all parts.

BTW: The frame on the picture was made with yellow PETG and black "green-tec", both from Extrudr.

title: Fish screw driver and bit storage

description.text:
Maybe you have a lot of bits for electric drills laying around like me, but no grip for them to use them as a screw driver. Here is an easy solution to fix this. Just print a fish grip, put the bit it (if necessary fix it permanently with some hot glue) and your ready to go.
If you have more than one bit lying around just print the bit storage fish and you will never lose any bits again. If you want to print more screw driver grips, I recommend to print them in different colors, so you can easily differ from the various bit types. Enjoy!

title: Creality CR-10 Anti-Tip Bracket and Tool Holder!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I was a having an issue with the Creality CR-10 pulling over the filament spool especially when it was full into the printer! Yes big ouch so I whiped these up and while one should work, two looks cool so up t you as should you print one and let it be lonely or two so it has company. Also worth note is the size of the of control box isn't perfect (are you surprised) so I made it for 125mm therefore you might find some extra rum between the uprights and the control box so use felt dots like these http://amzn.to/2u13kQ2 or you could also use velcro dots such these too http://amzn.to/2u0YkN1 in order to tighten the fit. In addition this was designed in Open SCAD and the code will be here (http://openscad.diy3dtech.com/creality-cr-10-antitip-bracket/) if you want to modify it.

Wondering how we designed this? Well check the Open SCAD video created over on our Open SCAD Channel: https://youtu.be/APVYF5Qcirs to find out more and if that still isn't enough check us out at our DIY3DTech channel too:https://youtu.be/LcrugZtBiBA

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.3 or better

Infill:

20% or So...

Notes:

Nothing major here just set and print, however these are big (since they are intended for the Creality CR-10) so be aware you will need a 300mm printer to print these.

comments.text: Thanks guy!  Just what I needed and only wish I found this before my recent print failure 3/4s through a large print that I had running overnight and when I got up the box had tipped over and the filament was jammed on the side of the windings.  A slight jerk and the filament came loose and I think if I had this anti-tip device it would have pulled it loose instead of tipping over stopping the print.
